channel.title: NYT > Movies
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Mark Your Calendar: The Tribeca Film Festival, Day by Day
item.media:description: Gilbert Gottfried in “Gilbert.”
item.description: To plan your itinerary, here are movies, talks and events, from a documentary on Gilbert Gottfried to “The Godfather.”
item.dc:creator: MIKE HALE

item.title: A Word With: After a Half-Century in Music, Clive Davis Is Still in Love
item.media:description: Clive Davis’s long career in the music business is the subject of a documentary opening the Tribeca Film Festival: “Clive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives.”
item.media:credit: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times
item.description: This executive’s long career is the subject of a new documentary, “Clive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives.”
item.dc:creator: BEN SISARIO
item.category: Clive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives (Movie)

item.title: ‘Fate of the Furious’ Slows at Home but Roars Overseas
item.media:description: Tyrese Gibson in “The Fate of the Furious,” the eighth chapter in one of Hollywood’s most popular movie series.
item.description: The latest chapter in the car-racing franchise took in $532.5 million worldwide in its opening weekend, one of the largest arrivals on record.
item.dc:creator: BROOKS BARNES

item.title: A Sisterhood of Scares
item.media:description: Sonya Lynch, 34, from Cincinnati, at HorrorHound.
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.description: What’s it like to be a female fan at a horror convention? Fifteen women spill their guts.
item.dc:creator: ERIK PIEPENBURG and MADDIE McGARVEY

item.title: Review: Family Values and Hot Rides in ‘Fate of the Furious’
item.media:description: Charlize Theron faces off against Vin Diesel in “The Fate of the Furious.”
item.description: Each installment of “Fast and Furious” is more enjoyably ludicrous than the last, even as the death of the star Paul Walker continues to hang over the franchise.
item.dc:creator: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: Review: ‘A Quiet Passion’ Poetically Captures Emily Dickinson
item.media:description: Cynthia Nixon as Emily Dickinson in “A Quiet Passion,” directed by Terence Davies.
item.description: Cynthia Nixon brings a great 19th-century American poet to vivid life in Terence Davies’s new film.
item.dc:creator: A. O. SCOTT

item.title: Review: Hearts of Darkness and Light in ‘The Lost City of Z’
item.media:description: Tom Holland, center left, and Charlie Hunnam, center right, in “The Lost City of Z.”
item.description: Charlie Hunnam stars in this period adventure story about love, loss and mystery in the Amazon from the director James Gray.
item.dc:creator: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: Anatomy of a Scene: F. Gary Gray on Shooting in Cuba for ‘The Fate of the Furious’
item.media:description: A scene from “The Fate of the Furious,” shot in Havana.
item.description: The director explains the challenges and thrills of filming in Havana, where his team was the first to shoot a sequence for a Hollywood film in more than 50 years.
item.dc:creator: MEKADO MURPHY

item.title: Hey, New York Film Lovers, Another Art House Is (Back) on the Scene
item.media:description: Charles S. Cohen, the film distributor and real estate developer who has bought and remodeled the Quad Cinema in Greenwich Village.
item.description: The Quad has gotten a modern makeover. Charles S. Cohen, the owner, explains why a theater makes sense in an age of screens in the palm of your hand.
item.dc:creator: MEKADO MURPHY

item.title: Playtime During the Previews? Playgrounds Are the Latest Movie Theater Accessories
item.media:description: Children play before watching a movie at the Cinépolis Junior movie theater in Pico Rivera, Calif.
item.description: Two California theaters have play areas in their auditoriums for 3- to 12-year-olds. But don’t worry, they’re not open while the show plays.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: A Word With: Steve Martin on Teaching You (and Himself) How to Be a Comedian
item.media:description: “I’ve always had empathy with comedians and their struggle,” said Steve Martin, who is now sharing lessons from his stand-up career. “I know it inside out, and the struggles remain the same.”
item.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Martin takes a rare, retrospective dive into his stand-up career to find lessons for aspiring comics and reflect on what he’s learned.
item.dc:creator: DAVE ITZKOFF

item.title: Disney’s ‘Frozen’ Musical Casts Its Princesses
item.media:description: Patti Murin, left, will play Anna and Caissie Levy, right, will play Elsa in a new musical adaptation of the animated film “Frozen.”
item.media:credit: From left: Rob Kim/Getty Images; Walt Disney Pictures; Michael Loccisano/Getty Images
item.description: Disney Theatrical Productions said Monday that it had chosen Caissie Levy to play Elsa and Patti Murin to play Anna in this adaptation of the 2013 film.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: Injured but Determined, Andy Karl Opens ‘Groundhog Day’
item.media:description: Andy Karl talks about his injury in a dressing room interview minutes after the opening performance of “Groundhog Day” on Broadway.
item.description: Three days after tearing his A.C.L. during a preview performance of the Broadway production, the actor put on a brace and put on a show.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: Clifton James, Who Played a Sheriff in 2 Bond Films, Dies at 96
item.media:description: Clifton James, right, and Roger Moore in a scene from “The Man With the Golden Gun” (1974).
item.description: Though he was born and raised in the Northwest, Mr. James often played a convincing Southerner in films like “Cool Hand Luke” and “Live and Let Die.”
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Andy Karl, Star of Musical ‘Groundhog Day,’ Is Injured During Preview
item.media:description: Andy Karl as Phil Connors in the musical “Groundhog Day” last month at the August Wilson Theater in New York.
item.description: Three days before the musical was set to open, its star hurt his knee. Saturday performances have been affected, and impact on opening night is unclear.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: Christopher Morahan, a Producer and Director of ‘The Jewel in the Crown,’ Dies at 87
item.media:description: The director Christopher Morahan, far left, with, from left, Michael Frayn, Michael Codron and John Cleese on the set of the film “Clockwise,” in 1986.
item.description: Beyond that heralded TV series and plays for television, Mr. Morahan’s career spanned the stage and film.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.category: The Jewel in the Crown (TV Program)

item.title: ‘Star Wars: The Last Jedi’ Movie Trailer Is Released
item.media:description: The character Rey in the opening of the trailer to “Star Wars: The Last Jedi.”
item.description: The official trailer is filled with images of characters from “The Force Awakens” but leaves plenty of mystery about what is to come.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Streaming: With ‘Tramps,’ Netflix Digs Deeper for Original Films
item.media:description: Grace Van Patten and Callum Turner in “Tramps,” coming to Netflix.
item.description: Adam Leon’s film, making its debut on April 21, will bypass theatrical release altogether after acclaim at the Toronto International Film Festival.
item.dc:creator: GLENN KENNY

item.title: This Week’s Movies: April 14, 2017
item.description: The New York Times film critics review “The Fate of the Furious,” “The Lost City of Z” and “Norman."

item.title: Film Series in NYC This Week
item.media:description: Mariangela Melato in “Love & Anarchy,” showing at the Quad as part of a Lina Wertmüller retrospective.
item.description: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
item.dc:creator: BEN KENIGSBERG

item.title: Review: In ‘Tommy’s Honour,’ a Family Feud on and Off the Green
item.media:description: Jack Lowden as Tommy Morris in “Tommy’s Honour.”
item.description: The director Jason Connery’s staid biopic is about the 19th-century golf pioneer Tom Morris and his son, with class conflict as a backdrop.
item.dc:creator: JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

item.title: Review: Angst, Jealousy and ‘My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea’
item.media:description: A scene from Dash Shaw’s animated feature “My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea.”
item.description: Teenage anxiety (voiced by Dash Shaw, Lena Dunham and others) takes a back seat to survival after an earthquake hits a cliffside high school.
item.dc:creator: GLENN KENNY
item.category: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (Movie)

item.title: Review: In ‘Mimosas,’ a Cryptic Mountain Trek
item.media:description: Saïd Aagli in “Mimosas,” directed by Oliver Laxe.
item.description: In following nomads on a mission in Morocco, this tale considers the fortifying power of faith, while scrambling the viewer’s sense of time.
item.dc:creator: JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

item.title: Review: ‘Maurizio Cattelan: Be Right Back’ Relishes a Mischievous Artist
item.media:description: “La Nona Ora,” an artwork imagining Pope John Paul II hit by a meteorite, is featured in “Maurizio Cattelan: Be Right Back.”
item.description: The documentary explores the artworks and pranks of an Italian trickster.
item.dc:creator: KEN JAWOROWSKI

item.title: Review: In ‘Little Boxes,’ a Biracial Family Meets a White Town
item.media:description: From left, Nelsan Ellis, Armani Jackson and Melanie Lynskey in “Little Boxes,” about a biracial family’s move from Brooklyn to small-town America.
item.description: A family ventures beyond the bubble of gentrified Brooklyn to a small town and is thrown out of its comfort zone.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GENZLINGER

item.title: Review: ‘Finding Oscar,’ and Hope, in Massacre’s Aftermath
item.media:description: Oscar Ramírez, right, the subject of the documentary “Finding Oscar,” with the soldier, also named Oscar, who abducted him.
item.description: This documentary looks at a Guatemalan village that was wiped out during a civil war, and searches for one of the few survivors.
item.dc:creator: KEN JAWOROWSKI
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Review: In ‘Chasing Trane,’ Where’s the Joy of Sax?
item.media:description: John Coltrane in John Scheinfeld’s documentary.
item.description: John Scheinfeld’s documentary about John Coltrane draws on interviews, including those with Bill Clinton, Carlos Santana and Cornel West.
item.dc:creator: BEN KENIGSBERG
item.category: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary (Movie)

item.title: Review: A Fragmented Past in ‘By the Time It Gets Dark’
item.media:description: A scene from Anocha Suwichakornpong’s “By the Time It Gets Dark.”
item.description: In examining a violent suppression of university protesters in Bangkok, this film uses a mutating narrative to reflect the impossibility of revisiting history.
item.dc:creator: BEN KENIGSBERG
item.category: By the Time It Gets Dark (Movie)

item.title: Review: ‘All These Sleepless Nights’ Roams the Streets of Warsaw
item.media:description: From left, Krzysztof Baginski, Eva Lebuef and Michal Huszcza in “All These Sleepless Nights,” directed by Michal Marczak.
item.description: A Polish film follows its young protagonist as he flirts, attends parties until dawn and gyrates to a perpetual backbeat.
item.dc:creator: BEN KENIGSBERG

item.title: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘The Fate of the Furious’
item.description: F. Gary Gray narrates a sequence from his film featuring Vin Diesel and Celestino Cornielle.

item.title: Review: ‘Heal the Living,’ a Sentimental Sales Pitch for Organ Donation
item.media:description: Gabin Verdet, center, plays the brain-dead son to Kool Shen, left, and Emmanuelle Seigner in “Heal the Living.”
item.description: Life, death and a heart transplant are at the center of this French film that moves among three distinct groups.
item.dc:creator: JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

item.title: A ‘Star Wars’ Salvo in the Toy-Store Gender Wars
item.media:description: Disney will roll out animated shorts and a related line of merchandise based on female “Star Wars” characters, above. The project is called “Star Wars Forces of Destiny.”
item.description: Disney animated shorts and merchandise will celebrate female characters. The initiative comes after critics took the company to task over lack of gender parity.
item.dc:creator: BROOKS BARNES

item.title: Cannes Film Festival Announces 2017 Lineup
item.media:description: The Cannes Film Festival, to be held May 17-28, opens with a lineup that includes 49 films from 29 countries, 12 of them by female directors.
item.description: Sofia Coppola, Noah Baumbach, Todd Haynes and Michael Haneke will be among the directors competing for this year’s Palme d’Or.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL DONADIO

item.title: Review: Richard Gere as ‘Norman,’ an Aspirational Fixer
item.media:description: Richard Gere as a compulsive schmoozer in “Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer,” directed by Joseph Cedar.
item.description: ‘Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer,’ Joseph Cedar’s latest film, pits Jew against Jew on the fringes of power and influence.
item.dc:creator: A. O. SCOTT

item.title: ‘Fantastic Beasts’ Has a New Dumbledore: Jude Law
item.media:description: Michael Gambon as Albus Dumbledore in “Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince” (2009).
item.description: The actor will play a younger version of the professor in the next installment of J.K. Rowling’s franchise.
item.dc:creator: CARA BUCKLEY
item.category: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (Movie)

item.title: A Second Bite of the Wonka Bar: Reimagining ‘Charlie’ for Broadway
item.media:description: A golden ticket: Jake Ryan Flynn as Charlie Bucket in “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” on Broadway.
item.description: The New York musical version of “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” required a new director, a new cast, a partial rewrite and old favorite songs.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: MoMA Explores Black Representation in Movies
item.media:description: Francine Everett as Gertie La Rue in “Dirty Gertie From Harlem U.S.A.,” part of “Making Faces on Film: A Collaboration With BFI Black Star,” at the Museum of Modern Art.
item.description: The program, “Making Faces on Film,” kicks off with a 1925 film by Oscar Micheaux featuring Paul Robeson in two roles.
item.dc:creator: ANDY WEBSTER

item.title: Oprah Winfrey on ‘The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks’
item.media:description: From left, Rose Byrne as Rebecca Skloot and Oprah Winfrey as Deborah Lacks in “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks.”
item.description: Ms. Winfrey, the star of the HBO film adaptation, talks about the book’s resonance and her reluctant decision to be in the movie.
item.dc:creator: SALAMISHAH TILLET
item.category: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks (Movie)
